page.title: 20THE VILLAGE, BEAFORD
page.content: Beaford has several examples of old cottages and buildings. Thatched cottages with cob walls can be seen at the Beehive and cottages further down Bond Street. These latter buildings once housed families working for local farmers, and often had large families occupying their small rooms. Several premises must date back to the 1600's; nearby farms much earlier that this. The farms however, have been much altered, and only small parts of original buildings remain. Upcott and Woolleigh are very old, being mentioned in the first Domesday, as was Beaford itself. The village now has a wide mixture of buildings, from the picturesque thatched cottage of previous centuries to stone buildings of the last century, to the modern block and brick built house and bungalow.
